trans-unit.source: Describes the concept of automation peers for Microsoft UI Automation, and how you can provide automation support for your own custom UI class.
trans-unit.target: Describes the concept of automation peers for Microsoft UI Automation, and how you can provide automation support for your own custom UI class.

trans-unit.source: Custom automation peers
trans-unit.target: Custom automation peers

trans-unit.source: Custom automation peers
trans-unit.target: Custom automation peers

trans-unit.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)

trans-unit.source: Describes the concept of automation peers for Microsoft UI Automation, and how you can provide automation support for your own custom UI class.
trans-unit.target: Describes the concept of automation peers for Microsoft UI Automation, and how you can provide automation support for your own custom UI class.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation provides a framework that automation clients can use to examine or operate the user interfaces of a variety of UI platforms and frameworks.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation provides a framework that automation clients can use to examine or operate the user interfaces of a variety of UI platforms and frameworks.

trans-unit.source: If you are writing a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, the classes that you use for your UI already provide UI Automation support.
trans-unit.target: If you are writing a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, the classes that you use for your UI already provide UI Automation support.

trans-unit.source: You can derive from existing, non-sealed classes to define a new kind of UI control or support class.
trans-unit.target: You can derive from existing, non-sealed classes to define a new kind of UI control or support class.

trans-unit.source: In the process of doing so, your class might add behavior that should have accessibility support but that the default UI Automation support does not cover.
trans-unit.target: In the process of doing so, your class might add behavior that should have accessibility support but that the default UI Automation support does not cover.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you should extend the existing UI Automation support by deriving from the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) class that the base implementation used, adding any necessary support to your peer implementation, and informing the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) control infrastructure that it should create your new peer.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you should extend the existing UI Automation support by deriving from the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) class that the base implementation used, adding any necessary support to your peer implementation, and informing the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) control infrastructure that it should create your new peer.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation enables not only accessibility applications and assistive technologies, such as screen readers, but also quality-assurance (test) code.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation enables not only accessibility applications and assistive technologies, such as screen readers, but also quality-assurance (test) code.

trans-unit.source: In either scenario, UI Automation clients can examine user-interface elements and simulate user interaction with your app from other code outside your app.
trans-unit.target: In either scenario, UI Automation clients can examine user-interface elements and simulate user interaction with your app from other code outside your app.

trans-unit.source: For info about UI Automation across all platforms and in its wider meaning, see [UI Automation Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684076).
trans-unit.target: For info about UI Automation across all platforms and in its wider meaning, see [UI Automation Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684076).

trans-unit.source: There are two distinct audiences who use the UI Automation framework.
trans-unit.target: There are two distinct audiences who use the UI Automation framework.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation *clients* call UI Automation APIs to learn about all of the UI that is currently displayed to the user.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation *clients* call UI Automation APIs to learn about all of the UI that is currently displayed to the user.

trans-unit.source: For example, an assistive technology such as a screen reader acts as a UI Automation client.
trans-unit.target: For example, an assistive technology such as a screen reader acts as a UI Automation client.

trans-unit.source: The UI is presented as a tree of automation elements that are related.
trans-unit.target: The UI is presented as a tree of automation elements that are related.

trans-unit.source: The UI Automation client might be interested in just one app at a time, or in the entire tree.
trans-unit.target: The UI Automation client might be interested in just one app at a time, or in the entire tree.

trans-unit.source: The UI Automation client can use UI Automation APIs to navigate the tree and to read or change information in the automation elements.
trans-unit.target: The UI Automation client can use UI Automation APIs to navigate the tree and to read or change information in the automation elements.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation *providers* contribute information to the UI Automation tree, by implementing APIs that expose the elements in the UI that they introduced as part of their app.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation *providers* contribute information to the UI Automation tree, by implementing APIs that expose the elements in the UI that they introduced as part of their app.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new control, you should now act as a participant in the UI Automation provider scenario.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new control, you should now act as a participant in the UI Automation provider scenario.

trans-unit.source: As a provider, you should ensure that all UI Automation clients can use the UI Automation framework to interact with your control for both accessibility and testing purposes.
trans-unit.target: As a provider, you should ensure that all UI Automation clients can use the UI Automation framework to interact with your control for both accessibility and testing purposes.

trans-unit.source: Typically there are parallel APIs in the UI Automation framework: one API for UI Automation clients and another, similarly named API for UI Automation providers.
trans-unit.target: Typically there are parallel APIs in the UI Automation framework: one API for UI Automation clients and another, similarly named API for UI Automation providers.

trans-unit.source: For the most part, this topic covers the APIs for the UI Automation provider, and specifically the classes and interfaces that enable provider extensibility in that UI framework.
trans-unit.target: For the most part, this topic covers the APIs for the UI Automation provider, and specifically the classes and interfaces that enable provider extensibility in that UI framework.

trans-unit.source: Occasionally we mention UI Automation APIs that the UI Automation clients use, to provide some perspective, or provide a lookup table that correlates the client and provider APIs.
trans-unit.target: Occasionally we mention UI Automation APIs that the UI Automation clients use, to provide some perspective, or provide a lookup table that correlates the client and provider APIs.

trans-unit.source: For more info about the client perspective, see [UI Automation Client Programmer's Guide](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684021).
trans-unit.target: For more info about the client perspective, see [UI Automation Client Programmer's Guide](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684021).

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: UI Automation clients don't typically use managed code and aren't typically implemented as a UWP app (they are usually desktop apps).
trans-unit.target: UI Automation clients don't typically use managed code and aren't typically implemented as a UWP app (they are usually desktop apps).

trans-unit.source: UI Automation is based on a standard and not a specific implementation or framework.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation is based on a standard and not a specific implementation or framework.

trans-unit.source: Many existing UI Automation clients, including assistive technology products such as screen readers, use Component Object Model (COM) interfaces to interact with UI Automation, the system, and the apps that run in child windows.
trans-unit.target: Many existing UI Automation clients, including assistive technology products such as screen readers, use Component Object Model (COM) interfaces to interact with UI Automation, the system, and the apps that run in child windows.

trans-unit.source: For more info on the COM interfaces and how to write a UI Automation client using COM, see [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).
trans-unit.target: For more info on the COM interfaces and how to write a UI Automation client using COM, see [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).

trans-unit.source: Determining the existing state of UI Automation support for your custom UI class
trans-unit.target: Determining the existing state of UI Automation support for your custom UI class

trans-unit.source: Before you attempt to implement an automation peer for a custom control, you should test whether the base class and its automation peer already provides the accessibility or automation support that you need.
trans-unit.target: Before you attempt to implement an automation peer for a custom control, you should test whether the base class and its automation peer already provides the accessibility or automation support that you need.

trans-unit.source: In many cases, the combination of the [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) implementations, specific peers, and the patterns they implement can provide a basic but satisfactory accessibility experience.
trans-unit.target: In many cases, the combination of the [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) implementations, specific peers, and the patterns they implement can provide a basic but satisfactory accessibility experience.

trans-unit.source: Whether this is true depends on how many changes you made to the object model exposure to your control versus its base class.
trans-unit.target: Whether this is true depends on how many changes you made to the object model exposure to your control versus its base class.

trans-unit.source: Also, this depends on whether your additions to base class functionality correlate to new UI elements in the template contract or to the visual appearance of the control.
trans-unit.target: Also, this depends on whether your additions to base class functionality correlate to new UI elements in the template contract or to the visual appearance of the control.

trans-unit.source: In some cases your changes might introduce new aspects of user experience that require additional accessibility support.
trans-unit.target: In some cases your changes might introduce new aspects of user experience that require additional accessibility support.

trans-unit.source: Even if using the existing base peer class provides the basic accessibility support, it is still a best practice to define a peer so that you can report precise **ClassName** information to UI Automation for automated testing scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Even if using the existing base peer class provides the basic accessibility support, it is still a best practice to define a peer so that you can report precise **ClassName** information to UI Automation for automated testing scenarios.

trans-unit.source: This consideration is especially important if you are writing a control that is intended for third-party consumption.
trans-unit.target: This consideration is especially important if you are writing a control that is intended for third-party consumption.

trans-unit.source: Automation peer classes
trans-unit.target: Automation peer classes

trans-unit.source: The UWP builds on existing UI Automation techniques and conventions used by previous managed-code UI frameworks such as Windows Forms, Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) and Microsoft Silverlight.
trans-unit.target: The UWP builds on existing UI Automation techniques and conventions used by previous managed-code UI frameworks such as Windows Forms, Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) and Microsoft Silverlight.

trans-unit.source: Many of the control classes and their function and purpose also have their origin in a previous UI framework.
trans-unit.target: Many of the control classes and their function and purpose also have their origin in a previous UI framework.

trans-unit.source: By convention, peer class names begin with the control class name and end with "AutomationPeer".
trans-unit.target: By convention, peer class names begin with the control class name and end with "AutomationPeer".

trans-unit.source: For example, [**ButtonAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242458) is the peer class for the [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209265) control class.
trans-unit.target: For example, [**ButtonAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242458) is the peer class for the [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209265) control class.

trans-unit.source: **Note** For purposes of this topic, we treat the properties that are related to accessibility as being more important when you implement a control peer.
trans-unit.target: **Note** For purposes of this topic, we treat the properties that are related to accessibility as being more important when you implement a control peer.

trans-unit.source: But for a more general concept of UI Automation support, you should implement a peer in accordance with recommendations as documented by the [UI Automation Provider Programmer's Guide](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671596) and [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).
trans-unit.target: But for a more general concept of UI Automation support, you should implement a peer in accordance with recommendations as documented by the [UI Automation Provider Programmer's Guide](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671596) and [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).

trans-unit.source: Those topics don't cover the specific [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) APIs that you would use to provide the information in the UWP framework for UI Automation, but they do describe the properties that identify your class or provide other information or interaction.
trans-unit.target: Those topics don't cover the specific [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) APIs that you would use to provide the information in the UWP framework for UI Automation, but they do describe the properties that identify your class or provide other information or interaction.

trans-unit.source: Peers, patterns and control types
trans-unit.target: Peers, patterns and control types

trans-unit.source: A *control pattern* is an interface implementation that exposes a particular aspect of a control's functionality to a UI Automation client.
trans-unit.target: A *control pattern* is an interface implementation that exposes a particular aspect of a control's functionality to a UI Automation client.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation clients use the properties and methods exposed through a control pattern to retrieve information about capabilities of the control, or to manipulate the control's behavior at run time.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation clients use the properties and methods exposed through a control pattern to retrieve information about capabilities of the control, or to manipulate the control's behavior at run time.

trans-unit.source: Control patterns provide a way to categorize and expose a control's functionality independent of the control type or the appearance of the control.
trans-unit.target: Control patterns provide a way to categorize and expose a control's functionality independent of the control type or the appearance of the control.

trans-unit.source: For example, a control that presents a tabular interface uses the **Grid** control pattern to expose the number of rows and columns in the table, and to enable a UI Automation client to retrieve items from the table.
trans-unit.target: For example, a control that presents a tabular interface uses the **Grid** control pattern to expose the number of rows and columns in the table, and to enable a UI Automation client to retrieve items from the table.

trans-unit.source: As other examples, the UI Automation client can use the **Invoke** control pattern for controls that can be invoked, such as buttons, and the **Scroll** control pattern for controls that have scroll bars, such as list boxes, list views, or combo boxes.
trans-unit.target: As other examples, the UI Automation client can use the **Invoke** control pattern for controls that can be invoked, such as buttons, and the **Scroll** control pattern for controls that have scroll bars, such as list boxes, list views, or combo boxes.

trans-unit.source: Each control pattern represents a separate type of functionality, and control patterns can be combined to describe the full set of functionality supported by a particular control.
trans-unit.target: Each control pattern represents a separate type of functionality, and control patterns can be combined to describe the full set of functionality supported by a particular control.

trans-unit.source: Control patterns relate to UI as interfaces relate to COM objects.
trans-unit.target: Control patterns relate to UI as interfaces relate to COM objects.

trans-unit.source: In COM, you can query an object to ask what interfaces it supports and then use those interfaces to access functionality.
trans-unit.target: In COM, you can query an object to ask what interfaces it supports and then use those interfaces to access functionality.

trans-unit.source: In UI Automation, UI Automation clients can query a UI Automation element to find out which control patterns it supports, and then interact with the element and its peered control through the properties, methods, events, and structures exposed by the supported control patterns.
trans-unit.target: In UI Automation, UI Automation clients can query a UI Automation element to find out which control patterns it supports, and then interact with the element and its peered control through the properties, methods, events, and structures exposed by the supported control patterns.

trans-unit.source: One of the main purposes of an automation peer is to report to a UI Automation client which control patterns the UI element can support through its peer.
trans-unit.target: One of the main purposes of an automation peer is to report to a UI Automation client which control patterns the UI element can support through its peer.

trans-unit.source: To do this, UI Automation providers implement new peers that change the [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) method behavior by overriding the [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method.
trans-unit.target: To do this, UI Automation providers implement new peers that change the [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) method behavior by overriding the [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation clients make calls that the UI Automation provider maps to calling **GetPattern**.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation clients make calls that the UI Automation provider maps to calling **GetPattern**.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation clients query for each specific pattern that they want to interact with.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation clients query for each specific pattern that they want to interact with.

trans-unit.source: If the peer supports the pattern, it returns an object reference to itself; otherwise it returns **null**.
trans-unit.target: If the peer supports the pattern, it returns an object reference to itself; otherwise it returns **null**.

trans-unit.source: If the return is not **null**, the UI Automation client expects that it can call APIs of the pattern interface as a client, in order to interact with that control pattern.
trans-unit.target: If the return is not **null**, the UI Automation client expects that it can call APIs of the pattern interface as a client, in order to interact with that control pattern.

trans-unit.source: A *control type* is a way to broadly define the functionality of a control that the peer represents.
trans-unit.target: A *control type* is a way to broadly define the functionality of a control that the peer represents.

trans-unit.source: This is a different concept than a control pattern because while a pattern informs UI Automation what info it can get or what actions it can perform through a particular interface, the control type exists one level above that.
trans-unit.target: This is a different concept than a control pattern because while a pattern informs UI Automation what info it can get or what actions it can perform through a particular interface, the control type exists one level above that.

trans-unit.source: Each control type has guidance about these aspects of UI Automation:
trans-unit.target: Each control type has guidance about these aspects of UI Automation:

trans-unit.source: UI Automation control patterns: A control type might support more than one pattern, each of which represents a different classification of info or interaction.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation control patterns: A control type might support more than one pattern, each of which represents a different classification of info or interaction.

trans-unit.source: Each control type has a set of control patterns that the control must support, a set that is optional, and a set that the control must not support.
trans-unit.target: Each control type has a set of control patterns that the control must support, a set that is optional, and a set that the control must not support.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation property values: Each control type has a set of properties that the control must support.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation property values: Each control type has a set of properties that the control must support.

trans-unit.source: These are the general properties, as described in [UI Automation Properties Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671594), not the ones that are pattern-specific.
trans-unit.target: These are the general properties, as described in [UI Automation Properties Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671594), not the ones that are pattern-specific.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation events: Each control type has a set of events that the control must support.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation events: Each control type has a set of events that the control must support.

trans-unit.source: Again these are general, not pattern-specific, as described in [UI Automation Events Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671221).
trans-unit.target: Again these are general, not pattern-specific, as described in [UI Automation Events Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671221).

trans-unit.source: UI Automation tree structure: Each control type defines how the control must appear in the UI Automation tree structure.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation tree structure: Each control type defines how the control must appear in the UI Automation tree structure.

trans-unit.source: Regardless of how automation peers for the framework are implemented, UI Automation client functionality isn't tied to the UWP, and in fact it's likely that existing UI Automation clients such as assistive technologies will use other programming models, such as COM.
trans-unit.target: Regardless of how automation peers for the framework are implemented, UI Automation client functionality isn't tied to the UWP, and in fact it's likely that existing UI Automation clients such as assistive technologies will use other programming models, such as COM.

trans-unit.source: In COM, clients can **QueryInterface** for the COM control pattern interface that implements the requested pattern or the general UI Automation framework for properties, events or tree examination.
trans-unit.target: In COM, clients can **QueryInterface** for the COM control pattern interface that implements the requested pattern or the general UI Automation framework for properties, events or tree examination.

trans-unit.source: For the patterns, the UI Automation framework marshals that interface code across into UWP code running against the app's UI Automation provider and the relevant peer.
trans-unit.target: For the patterns, the UI Automation framework marshals that interface code across into UWP code running against the app's UI Automation provider and the relevant peer.

trans-unit.source: When you implement control patterns for a managed-code framework such as a Windows Store app using C\# or Microsoft Visual Basic, you can use .NET Framework interfaces to represent these patterns instead of using the COM interface representation.
trans-unit.target: When you implement control patterns for a managed-code framework such as a Windows Store app using C\# or Microsoft Visual Basic, you can use .NET Framework interfaces to represent these patterns instead of using the COM interface representation.

trans-unit.source: For example, the UI Automation pattern interface for a Microsoft .NET provider implementation of the **Invoke** pattern is [**IInvokeProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242582).
trans-unit.target: For example, the UI Automation pattern interface for a Microsoft .NET provider implementation of the **Invoke** pattern is [**IInvokeProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242582).

trans-unit.source: For a list of control patterns, provider interfaces, and their purpose, see [Control patterns and interfaces](control-patterns-and-interfaces.md).
trans-unit.target: For a list of control patterns, provider interfaces, and their purpose, see [Control patterns and interfaces](control-patterns-and-interfaces.md).

trans-unit.source: For the list of the control types, see [UI Automation Control Types Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671197).
trans-unit.target: For the list of the control types, see [UI Automation Control Types Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671197).

trans-unit.source: Guidance for how to implement control patterns
trans-unit.target: Guidance for how to implement control patterns

trans-unit.source: The control patterns and what they're intended for are part of a larger definition of the UI Automation framework, and don't just apply to the accessibility support for a Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: The control patterns and what they're intended for are part of a larger definition of the UI Automation framework, and don't just apply to the accessibility support for a Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: When you implement a control pattern you should make sure you're implementing it in a way that matches the guidance as documented on MSDN and also in the UI Automation specification.
trans-unit.target: When you implement a control pattern you should make sure you're implementing it in a way that matches the guidance as documented on MSDN and also in the UI Automation specification.

trans-unit.source: If you're looking for guidance, you can generally use the MSDN topics and won't need to refer to the specification.
trans-unit.target: If you're looking for guidance, you can generally use the MSDN topics and won't need to refer to the specification.

trans-unit.source: Guidance for each pattern is documented here: [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292).
trans-unit.target: Guidance for each pattern is documented here: [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292).

trans-unit.source: You'll notice that each topic under this area has an "Implementation Guidelines and Conventions" section and "Required Members" section.
trans-unit.target: You'll notice that each topic under this area has an "Implementation Guidelines and Conventions" section and "Required Members" section.

trans-unit.source: The guidance usually refers to specific APIs of the relevant control pattern interface in the [Control Pattern Interfaces for Providers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671201) reference.
trans-unit.target: The guidance usually refers to specific APIs of the relevant control pattern interface in the [Control Pattern Interfaces for Providers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671201) reference.

trans-unit.source: Those interfaces are the native/COM interfaces (and their APIs use COM-style syntax).
trans-unit.target: Those interfaces are the native/COM interfaces (and their APIs use COM-style syntax).

trans-unit.source: But everything you see there has an equivalent in the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225) namespace.
trans-unit.target: But everything you see there has an equivalent in the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225) namespace.

trans-unit.source: If you're using the default automation peers and expanding on their behavior, those peers have already been written in conformance to UI Automation guidelines.
trans-unit.target: If you're using the default automation peers and expanding on their behavior, those peers have already been written in conformance to UI Automation guidelines.

trans-unit.source: If they support control patterns, you can rely on that pattern support conforming with guidance at [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292).
trans-unit.target: If they support control patterns, you can rely on that pattern support conforming with guidance at [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292).

trans-unit.source: If a control peer reports that it's representative of a control type defined by UI Automation, then the guidance documented at [Supporting UI Automation Control Types](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671633) has been followed by that peer.
trans-unit.target: If a control peer reports that it's representative of a control type defined by UI Automation, then the guidance documented at [Supporting UI Automation Control Types](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671633) has been followed by that peer.

trans-unit.source: Nevertheless you might need additional guidance for control patterns or control types in order to follow the UI Automation recommendations in your peer implementation.
trans-unit.target: Nevertheless you might need additional guidance for control patterns or control types in order to follow the UI Automation recommendations in your peer implementation.

trans-unit.source: That would be particularly true if you're implementing pattern or control type support that doesn't yet exist as a default implementation in a UWP control.
trans-unit.target: That would be particularly true if you're implementing pattern or control type support that doesn't yet exist as a default implementation in a UWP control.

trans-unit.source: For example, the pattern for annotations isn't implemented in any of the default XAML controls.
trans-unit.target: For example, the pattern for annotations isn't implemented in any of the default XAML controls.

trans-unit.source: But you might have an app that uses annotations extensively and therefore you want to surface that functionality to be accessible.
trans-unit.target: But you might have an app that uses annotations extensively and therefore you want to surface that functionality to be accessible.

trans-unit.source: For this scenario, your peer should implement [**IAnnotationProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh738493) and should probably report itself as the **Document** control type with appropriate properties to indicate that your documents support annotation.
trans-unit.target: For this scenario, your peer should implement [**IAnnotationProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh738493) and should probably report itself as the **Document** control type with appropriate properties to indicate that your documents support annotation.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you use the guidance that you see for the patterns under [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292) or control types under [Supporting UI Automation Control Types](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671633) as orientation and general guidance.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you use the guidance that you see for the patterns under [Implementing UI Automation Control Patterns](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671292) or control types under [Supporting UI Automation Control Types](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671633) as orientation and general guidance.

trans-unit.source: You might even try following some of the API links for descriptions and remarks as to the purpose of the APIs.
trans-unit.target: You might even try following some of the API links for descriptions and remarks as to the purpose of the APIs.

trans-unit.source: But for syntax specifics that are needed for UWP app programming, find the equivalent API within the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225) namespace and use those reference pages for more info.
trans-unit.target: But for syntax specifics that are needed for UWP app programming, find the equivalent API within the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225) namespace and use those reference pages for more info.

trans-unit.source: Built-in automation peer classes
trans-unit.target: Built-in automation peer classes

trans-unit.source: In general, elements implement an automation peer class if they accept UI activity from the user, or if they contain information needed by users of assistive technologies that represent the interactive or meaningful UI of apps.
trans-unit.target: In general, elements implement an automation peer class if they accept UI activity from the user, or if they contain information needed by users of assistive technologies that represent the interactive or meaningful UI of apps.

trans-unit.source: Not all UWP visual elements have automation peers.
trans-unit.target: Not all UWP visual elements have automation peers.

trans-unit.source: Examples of classes that implement automation peers are [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209265) and [**TextBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209683).
trans-unit.target: Examples of classes that implement automation peers are [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209265) and [**TextBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209683).

trans-unit.source: Examples of classes that do not implement automation peers are [**Border**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209250) and classes based on [**Panel**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227511), such as [**Grid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242704) and [**Canvas**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209267).
trans-unit.target: Examples of classes that do not implement automation peers are [**Border**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209250) and classes based on [**Panel**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227511), such as [**Grid**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242704) and [**Canvas**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209267).

trans-unit.source: A **Panel** has no peer because it is providing a layout behavior that is visual only.
trans-unit.target: A **Panel** has no peer because it is providing a layout behavior that is visual only.

trans-unit.source: There is no accessibility-relevant way for the user to interact with a **Panel**.
trans-unit.target: There is no accessibility-relevant way for the user to interact with a **Panel**.

trans-unit.source: Whatever child elements a **Panel** contains are instead reported to UI Automation trees as child elements of the next available parent in the tree that has a peer or element representation.
trans-unit.target: Whatever child elements a **Panel** contains are instead reported to UI Automation trees as child elements of the next available parent in the tree that has a peer or element representation.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation and UWP process boundaries
trans-unit.target: UI Automation and UWP process boundaries

trans-unit.source: Typically, UI Automation client code that accesses a UWP app runs out-of-process.
trans-unit.target: Typically, UI Automation client code that accesses a UWP app runs out-of-process.

trans-unit.source: The UI Automation framework infrastructure enables information to get across the process boundary.
trans-unit.target: The UI Automation framework infrastructure enables information to get across the process boundary.

trans-unit.source: This concept is explained in more detail in [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).
trans-unit.target: This concept is explained in more detail in [UI Automation Fundamentals](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee684007).

trans-unit.source: OnCreateAutomationPeer
trans-unit.target: OnCreateAutomationPeer

trans-unit.source: All classes that derive from [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911) contain the protected virtual method [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer).
trans-unit.target: All classes that derive from [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911) contain the protected virtual method [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer).

trans-unit.source: The object initialization sequence for automation peers calls **OnCreateAutomationPeer** to get the automation peer object for each control and thus to construct a UI Automation tree for run-time use.
trans-unit.target: The object initialization sequence for automation peers calls **OnCreateAutomationPeer** to get the automation peer object for each control and thus to construct a UI Automation tree for run-time use.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation code can use the peer to get information about a controls characteristics and features and to simulate interactive use by means of its control patterns.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation code can use the peer to get information about a controls characteristics and features and to simulate interactive use by means of its control patterns.

trans-unit.source: A custom control that supports automation must override **OnCreateAutomationPeer** and return an instance of a class that derives from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185).
trans-unit.target: A custom control that supports automation must override **OnCreateAutomationPeer** and return an instance of a class that derives from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185).

trans-unit.source: For example, if a custom control derives from the [**ButtonBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227736) class, the object returned by **OnCreateAutomationPeer** should derive from [**ButtonBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242460).
trans-unit.target: For example, if a custom control derives from the [**ButtonBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227736) class, the object returned by **OnCreateAutomationPeer** should derive from [**ButtonBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242460).

trans-unit.source: If you're writing a custom control class and intend to also supply a new automation peer, you should override the [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) method for your custom control so that it returns a new instance of your peer.
trans-unit.target: If you're writing a custom control class and intend to also supply a new automation peer, you should override the [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) method for your custom control so that it returns a new instance of your peer.

trans-unit.source: Your peer class must derive directly or indirectly from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185).
trans-unit.target: Your peer class must derive directly or indirectly from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185).

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code declares that the custom control 'NumericUpDown' should use the peer 'NumericUpDownPeer' for UI Automation purposes.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code declares that the custom control 'NumericUpDown' should use the peer 'NumericUpDownPeer' for UI Automation purposes.

trans-unit.source: **Note** The [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) implementation should do nothing more than initialize a new instance of your custom automation peer, passing the calling control as owner, and return that instance.
trans-unit.target: **Note** The [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) implementation should do nothing more than initialize a new instance of your custom automation peer, passing the calling control as owner, and return that instance.

trans-unit.source: Do not attempt additional logic in this method.
trans-unit.target: Do not attempt additional logic in this method.

trans-unit.source: In particular, any logic that could potentially lead to destruction of the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) within the same call may result in unexpected runtime behavior.
trans-unit.target: In particular, any logic that could potentially lead to destruction of the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) within the same call may result in unexpected runtime behavior.

trans-unit.source: In typical implementations of [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer), the *owner* is specified as **this** or **Me** because the method override is in the same scope as the rest of the control class definition.
trans-unit.target: In typical implementations of [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer), the *owner* is specified as **this** or **Me** because the method override is in the same scope as the rest of the control class definition.

trans-unit.source: The actual peer class definition can be done in the same code file as the control or in a separate code file.
trans-unit.target: The actual peer class definition can be done in the same code file as the control or in a separate code file.

trans-unit.source: The peer definitions all exist in the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Peers**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242563) namespace that is a separate namespace from the controls that they provide peers for.
trans-unit.target: The peer definitions all exist in the [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Peers**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242563) namespace that is a separate namespace from the controls that they provide peers for.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to declare your peers in separate namespaces also, as long as you reference the necessary namespaces for the [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) method call.
trans-unit.target: You can choose to declare your peers in separate namespaces also, as long as you reference the necessary namespaces for the [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) method call.

trans-unit.source: Choosing the correct peer base class
trans-unit.target: Choosing the correct peer base class

trans-unit.source: Make sure that your [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) is derived from a base class that gives you the best match for the existing peer logic of the control class you are deriving from.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that your [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) is derived from a base class that gives you the best match for the existing peer logic of the control class you are deriving from.

trans-unit.source: In the case of the previous example, because `NumericUpDown` derives from [**RangeBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227863), there is a [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506) class available that you should base your peer on.
trans-unit.target: In the case of the previous example, because `NumericUpDown` derives from [**RangeBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227863), there is a [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506) class available that you should base your peer on.

trans-unit.source: By using the closest matching peer class in parallel to how you derive the control itself, you can avoid overriding at least some of the [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) functionality because the base peer class already implements it.
trans-unit.target: By using the closest matching peer class in parallel to how you derive the control itself, you can avoid overriding at least some of the [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) functionality because the base peer class already implements it.

trans-unit.source: The base [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390) class does not have a corresponding peer class.
trans-unit.target: The base [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390) class does not have a corresponding peer class.

trans-unit.source: If you need a peer class to correspond to a custom control that derives from **Control**, derive the custom peer class from [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472).
trans-unit.target: If you need a peer class to correspond to a custom control that derives from **Control**, derive the custom peer class from [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472).

trans-unit.source: If you derive from [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365) directly, that class has no default automation peer behavior because there is no [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) implementation that references a peer class.
trans-unit.target: If you derive from [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365) directly, that class has no default automation peer behavior because there is no [**OnCreateAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_oncreateautomationpeer) implementation that references a peer class.

trans-unit.source: So make sure either to implement **OnCreateAutomationPeer** to use your own peer, or to use [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) as the peer if that level of accessibility support is adequate for your control.
trans-unit.target: So make sure either to implement **OnCreateAutomationPeer** to use your own peer, or to use [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) as the peer if that level of accessibility support is adequate for your control.

trans-unit.source: **Note** You don't typically derive from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) rather than [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472).
trans-unit.target: **Note** You don't typically derive from [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) rather than [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472).

trans-unit.source: If you did derive directly from **AutomationPeer** you'll need to duplicate a lot of basic accessibility support that would otherwise come from **FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**.
trans-unit.target: If you did derive directly from **AutomationPeer** you'll need to duplicate a lot of basic accessibility support that would otherwise come from **FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**.

trans-unit.source: Initialization of a custom peer class
trans-unit.target: Initialization of a custom peer class

trans-unit.source: The automation peer should define a type-safe constructor that uses an instance of the owner control for base initialization.
trans-unit.target: The automation peer should define a type-safe constructor that uses an instance of the owner control for base initialization.

trans-unit.source: In the next example, the implementation passes the *owner* value on to the [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506) base, and ultimately it is the [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) that actually uses *owner* to set [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer.Owner**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_owner).
trans-unit.target: In the next example, the implementation passes the *owner* value on to the [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506) base, and ultimately it is the [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) that actually uses *owner* to set [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer.Owner**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_owner).

trans-unit.source: Core methods of AutomationPeer
trans-unit.target: Core methods of AutomationPeer

trans-unit.source: For UWP infrastructure reasons, the overridable methods of an automation peer are part of a pair of methods: the public access method that the UI Automation provider uses as a forwarding point for UI Automation clients, and the protected "Core" customization method that a UWP class can override to influence the behavior.
trans-unit.target: For UWP infrastructure reasons, the overridable methods of an automation peer are part of a pair of methods: the public access method that the UI Automation provider uses as a forwarding point for UI Automation clients, and the protected "Core" customization method that a UWP class can override to influence the behavior.

trans-unit.source: The method pair is wired together by default in such a way that the call to the access method always invokes the parallel "Core" method that has the provider implementation, or as a fallback, invokes a default implementation from the base classes.
trans-unit.target: The method pair is wired together by default in such a way that the call to the access method always invokes the parallel "Core" method that has the provider implementation, or as a fallback, invokes a default implementation from the base classes.

trans-unit.source: When implementing a peer for a custom control, override any of the "Core" methods from the base automation peer class where you want to expose behavior that is unique to your custom control.
trans-unit.target: When implementing a peer for a custom control, override any of the "Core" methods from the base automation peer class where you want to expose behavior that is unique to your custom control.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation code gets information about your control by calling public methods of the peer class.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation code gets information about your control by calling public methods of the peer class.

trans-unit.source: To provide information about your control, override each method with a name that ends with "Core" when your control implementation and design creates accessibility scenarios or other UI Automation scenarios that differ from what's supported by the base automation peer class.
trans-unit.target: To provide information about your control, override each method with a name that ends with "Core" when your control implementation and design creates accessibility scenarios or other UI Automation scenarios that differ from what's supported by the base automation peer class.

trans-unit.source: At a minimum, whenever you define a new peer class, implement the [**GetClassNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclassnamecore) method, as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: At a minimum, whenever you define a new peer class, implement the [**GetClassNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclassnamecore) method, as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: **Note** You might want to store the strings as constants rather than directly in the method body, but that is up to you.
trans-unit.target: **Note** You might want to store the strings as constants rather than directly in the method body, but that is up to you.

trans-unit.source: For [**GetClassNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclassnamecore), you won't need to localize this string.
trans-unit.target: For [**GetClassNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclassnamecore), you won't need to localize this string.

trans-unit.source: The **LocalizedControlType** property is used any time a localized string is needed by a UI Automation client, not **ClassName**.
trans-unit.target: The **LocalizedControlType** property is used any time a localized string is needed by a UI Automation client, not **ClassName**.

trans-unit.source: GetAutomationControlType
trans-unit.target: GetAutomationControlType

trans-unit.source: Some assistive technologies use the [**GetAutomationControlType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltype) value directly when reporting characteristics of the items in a UI Automation tree, as additional information beyond the UI Automation **Name**.
trans-unit.target: Some assistive technologies use the [**GetAutomationControlType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltype) value directly when reporting characteristics of the items in a UI Automation tree, as additional information beyond the UI Automation **Name**.

trans-unit.source: If your control is significantly different from the control you are deriving from and you want to report a different control type from what is reported by the base peer class used by the control, you must implement a peer and override [**GetAutomationControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltypecore) in your peer implementation.
trans-unit.target: If your control is significantly different from the control you are deriving from and you want to report a different control type from what is reported by the base peer class used by the control, you must implement a peer and override [**GetAutomationControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltypecore) in your peer implementation.

trans-unit.source: This is particularly important if you derive from a generalized base class such as [**ItemsControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242803) or [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365), where the base peer doesn't provide precise information about control type.
trans-unit.target: This is particularly important if you derive from a generalized base class such as [**ItemsControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242803) or [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365), where the base peer doesn't provide precise information about control type.

trans-unit.source: Your implementation of [**GetAutomationControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltypecore) describes your control by returning an [**AutomationControlType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209182) value.
trans-unit.target: Your implementation of [**GetAutomationControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getautomationcontroltypecore) describes your control by returning an [**AutomationControlType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209182) value.

trans-unit.source: Although you can return **AutomationControlType.Custom**, you should return one of the more specific control types if it accurately describes your control's main scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Although you can return **AutomationControlType.Custom**, you should return one of the more specific control types if it accurately describes your control's main scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Unless you specify [**AutomationControlType.Custom**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209182), you don't have to implement [**GetLocalizedControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlocalizedcontroltypecore) to provide a **LocalizedControlType** property value to clients.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Unless you specify [**AutomationControlType.Custom**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209182), you don't have to implement [**GetLocalizedControlTypeCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlocalizedcontroltypecore) to provide a **LocalizedControlType** property value to clients.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation common infrastructure provides translated strings for every possible **AutomationControlType** value other than **AutomationControlType.Custom**.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation common infrastructure provides translated strings for every possible **AutomationControlType** value other than **AutomationControlType.Custom**.

trans-unit.source: GetPattern and GetPatternCore
trans-unit.target: GetPattern and GetPatternCore

trans-unit.source: A peer's implementation of [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) returns the object that supports the pattern that is requested in the input parameter.
trans-unit.target: A peer's implementation of [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) returns the object that supports the pattern that is requested in the input parameter.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, a UI Automation client calls a method that is forwarded to the provider's [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) method, and specifies a [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) enumeration value that names the requested pattern.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, a UI Automation client calls a method that is forwarded to the provider's [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) method, and specifies a [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) enumeration value that names the requested pattern.

trans-unit.source: Your override of **GetPatternCore** should return the object that implements the specified pattern.
trans-unit.target: Your override of **GetPatternCore** should return the object that implements the specified pattern.

trans-unit.source: That object is the peer itself, because the peer should implement the corresponding pattern interface any time that it reports that it supports a pattern.
trans-unit.target: That object is the peer itself, because the peer should implement the corresponding pattern interface any time that it reports that it supports a pattern.

trans-unit.source: If your peer does not have a custom implementation of a pattern, but you know that the peer's base does implement the pattern, you can call the base type's implementation of **GetPatternCore** from your **GetPatternCore**.
trans-unit.target: If your peer does not have a custom implementation of a pattern, but you know that the peer's base does implement the pattern, you can call the base type's implementation of **GetPatternCore** from your **GetPatternCore**.

trans-unit.source: A peer's **GetPatternCore** should return **null** if a pattern is not supported by the peer.
trans-unit.target: A peer's **GetPatternCore** should return **null** if a pattern is not supported by the peer.

trans-unit.source: However, instead of returning **null** directly from your implementation, you would usually rely on the call to the base implementation to return **null** for any unsupported pattern.
trans-unit.target: However, instead of returning **null** directly from your implementation, you would usually rely on the call to the base implementation to return **null** for any unsupported pattern.

trans-unit.source: When a pattern is supported, the [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) implementation can return **this** or **Me**.
trans-unit.target: When a pattern is supported, the [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) implementation can return **this** or **Me**.

trans-unit.source: The expectation is that the UI Automation client will cast the [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) return value to the requested pattern interface whenever it is not **null**.
trans-unit.target: The expectation is that the UI Automation client will cast the [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) return value to the requested pattern interface whenever it is not **null**.

trans-unit.source: If a peer class inherits from another peer, and all necessary support and pattern reporting is already handled by the base class, implementing [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) isn't necessary.
trans-unit.target: If a peer class inherits from another peer, and all necessary support and pattern reporting is already handled by the base class, implementing [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) isn't necessary.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are implementing a range control that derives from [**RangeBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227863), and your peer derives from [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506), that peer returns itself for [**PatternInterface.RangeValue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) and has working implementations of the [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) interface that supports the pattern.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are implementing a range control that derives from [**RangeBase**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227863), and your peer derives from [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506), that peer returns itself for [**PatternInterface.RangeValue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) and has working implementations of the [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) interface that supports the pattern.

trans-unit.source: Although it is not the literal code, this example approximates the implementation of [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) already present in [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506).
trans-unit.target: Although it is not the literal code, this example approximates the implementation of [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) already present in [**RangeBaseAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242506).

trans-unit.source: If you are implementing a peer where you don't have all the support you need from a base peer class, or you want to change or add to the set of base-inherited patterns that your peer can support, then you should override [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) to enable UI Automation clients to use the patterns.
trans-unit.target: If you are implementing a peer where you don't have all the support you need from a base peer class, or you want to change or add to the set of base-inherited patterns that your peer can support, then you should override [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) to enable UI Automation clients to use the patterns.

trans-unit.source: For a list of the provider patterns that are available in the UWP implementation of UI Automation support, see [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225).
trans-unit.target: For a list of the provider patterns that are available in the UWP implementation of UI Automation support, see [**Windows.UI.Xaml.Automation.Provider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209225).

trans-unit.source: Each such pattern has a corresponding value of the [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) enumeration, which is how UI Automation clients request the pattern in a [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) call.
trans-unit.target: Each such pattern has a corresponding value of the [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) enumeration, which is how UI Automation clients request the pattern in a [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) call.

trans-unit.source: A peer can report that it supports more than one pattern.
trans-unit.target: A peer can report that it supports more than one pattern.

trans-unit.source: If so, the override should include return path logic for each supported [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) value and return the peer in each matching case.
trans-unit.target: If so, the override should include return path logic for each supported [**PatternInterface**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496) value and return the peer in each matching case.

trans-unit.source: It is expected that the caller will request only one interface at a time, and it is up to the caller to cast to the expected interface.
trans-unit.target: It is expected that the caller will request only one interface at a time, and it is up to the caller to cast to the expected interface.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of a [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) override for a custom peer.

trans-unit.source: It reports the support for two patterns, [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) and [**IToggleProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242653).
trans-unit.target: It reports the support for two patterns, [**IRangeValueProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242590) and [**IToggleProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242653).

trans-unit.source: The control here is a media display control that can display as full-screen (the toggle mode) and that has a progress bar within which users can select a position (the range control).
