trans-unit.source: Forwarding patterns from subelements
trans-unit.target: Forwarding patterns from subelements

trans-unit.source: A [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method implementation can also specify a subelement or part as a pattern provider for its host.
trans-unit.target: A [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method implementation can also specify a subelement or part as a pattern provider for its host.

trans-unit.source: This example mimics how [**ItemsControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242803) transfers scroll-pattern handling to the peer of its internal [**ScrollViewer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209527) control.
trans-unit.target: This example mimics how [**ItemsControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242803) transfers scroll-pattern handling to the peer of its internal [**ScrollViewer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209527) control.

trans-unit.source: To specify a subelement for pattern handling, this code gets the subelement object, creates a peer for the subelement by using the [**FrameworkElement.CreatePeerForElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_createpeerforelement) method, and returns the new peer.
trans-unit.target: To specify a subelement for pattern handling, this code gets the subelement object, creates a peer for the subelement by using the [**FrameworkElement.CreatePeerForElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_createpeerforelement) method, and returns the new peer.

trans-unit.source: Other Core methods
trans-unit.target: Other Core methods

trans-unit.source: Your control may need to support keyboard equivalents for primary scenarios; for more info about why this might be necessary, see [Keyboard accessibility](keyboard-accessibility.md).
trans-unit.target: Your control may need to support keyboard equivalents for primary scenarios; for more info about why this might be necessary, see [Keyboard accessibility](keyboard-accessibility.md).

trans-unit.source: Implementing the key support is necessarily part of the control code and not the peer code because that is part of a control's logic, but your peer class should override the [**GetAcceleratorKeyCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getacceleratorkeycore) and [**GetAccessKeyCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getaccesskeycore) methods to report to UI Automation clients which keys are used.
trans-unit.target: Implementing the key support is necessarily part of the control code and not the peer code because that is part of a control's logic, but your peer class should override the [**GetAcceleratorKeyCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getacceleratorkeycore) and [**GetAccessKeyCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getaccesskeycore) methods to report to UI Automation clients which keys are used.

trans-unit.source: Consider that the strings that report key information might need to be localized, and should therefore come from resources, not hard-coded strings.
trans-unit.target: Consider that the strings that report key information might need to be localized, and should therefore come from resources, not hard-coded strings.

trans-unit.source: If you are providing a peer for a class that supports a collection, it's best to derive from both functional classes and peer classes that already have that kind of collection support.
trans-unit.target: If you are providing a peer for a class that supports a collection, it's best to derive from both functional classes and peer classes that already have that kind of collection support.

trans-unit.source: If you can't do so, peers for controls that maintain child collections may have to override the collection-related peer method [**GetChildrenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildrencore) to properly report the parent-child relationships to the UI Automation tree.
trans-unit.target: If you can't do so, peers for controls that maintain child collections may have to override the collection-related peer method [**GetChildrenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildrencore) to properly report the parent-child relationships to the UI Automation tree.

trans-unit.source: Implement the [**IsContentElementCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iscontentelementcore) and [**IsControlElementCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iscontrolelementcore) methods to indicate whether your control contains data content or fulfills an interactive role in the user interface (or both).
trans-unit.target: Implement the [**IsContentElementCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iscontentelementcore) and [**IsControlElementCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iscontrolelementcore) methods to indicate whether your control contains data content or fulfills an interactive role in the user interface (or both).

trans-unit.source: By default, both methods return **true**.
trans-unit.target: By default, both methods return **true**.

trans-unit.source: These settings improve the usability of assistive technologies such as screen readers, which may use these methods to filter the automation tree.
trans-unit.target: These settings improve the usability of assistive technologies such as screen readers, which may use these methods to filter the automation tree.

trans-unit.source: If your [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method transfers pattern handling to a subelement peer, the subelement peer's **IsControlElementCore** method can return **false** to hide the subelement peer from the automation tree.
trans-unit.target: If your [**GetPatternCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpatterncore) method transfers pattern handling to a subelement peer, the subelement peer's **IsControlElementCore** method can return **false** to hide the subelement peer from the automation tree.

trans-unit.source: Some controls may support labeling scenarios, where a text label part supplies information for a non-text part, or a control is intended to be in a known labeling relationship with another control in the UI.
trans-unit.target: Some controls may support labeling scenarios, where a text label part supplies information for a non-text part, or a control is intended to be in a known labeling relationship with another control in the UI.

trans-unit.source: If it's possible to provide a useful class-based behavior, you can override [**GetLabeledByCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlabeledbycore) to provide this behavior.
trans-unit.target: If it's possible to provide a useful class-based behavior, you can override [**GetLabeledByCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlabeledbycore) to provide this behavior.

trans-unit.source: [**GetBoundingRectangleCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getboundingrectanglecore) and [**GetClickablePointCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclickablepointcore) are used mainly for automated testing scenarios.
trans-unit.target: [**GetBoundingRectangleCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getboundingrectanglecore) and [**GetClickablePointCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclickablepointcore) are used mainly for automated testing scenarios.

trans-unit.source: If you want to support automated testing for your control, you might want to override these methods.
trans-unit.target: If you want to support automated testing for your control, you might want to override these methods.

trans-unit.source: This might be desired for range-type controls, where you can't suggest just a single point because where the user clicks in coordinate space has a different effect on a range.
trans-unit.target: This might be desired for range-type controls, where you can't suggest just a single point because where the user clicks in coordinate space has a different effect on a range.

trans-unit.source: For example, the default [**ScrollBar**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209745) automation peer overrides **GetClickablePointCore** to return a "not a number" [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) value.
trans-unit.target: For example, the default [**ScrollBar**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209745) automation peer overrides **GetClickablePointCore** to return a "not a number" [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) value.

trans-unit.source: [**GetLiveSettingCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlivesettingcore) influences the control default for the **LiveSetting** value for UI Automation.
trans-unit.target: [**GetLiveSettingCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlivesettingcore) influences the control default for the **LiveSetting** value for UI Automation.

trans-unit.source: You might want to override this if you want your control to return a value other than [**AutomationLiveSetting.Off**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/JJ191519).
trans-unit.target: You might want to override this if you want your control to return a value other than [**AutomationLiveSetting.Off**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/JJ191519).

trans-unit.source: For more info on what **LiveSetting** represents, see [**AutomationProperties.LiveSetting**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/JJ191516).
trans-unit.target: For more info on what **LiveSetting** represents, see [**AutomationProperties.LiveSetting**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/JJ191516).

trans-unit.source: You might override [**GetOrientationCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getorientationcore) if your control has a settable orientation property that can map to [**AutomationOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209184).
trans-unit.target: You might override [**GetOrientationCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getorientationcore) if your control has a settable orientation property that can map to [**AutomationOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209184).

trans-unit.source: The [**ScrollBarAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242522) and [**SliderAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242546) classes do this.
trans-unit.target: The [**ScrollBarAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242522) and [**SliderAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242546) classes do this.

trans-unit.source: Base implementation in FrameworkElementAutomationPeer
trans-unit.target: Base implementation in FrameworkElementAutomationPeer

trans-unit.source: The base implementation of [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) provides some UI Automation information that can be interpreted from various layout and behavior properties that are defined at the framework level.
trans-unit.target: The base implementation of [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) provides some UI Automation information that can be interpreted from various layout and behavior properties that are defined at the framework level.

trans-unit.source: [**GetBoundingRectangleCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getboundingrectanglecore): Returns a [**Rect**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225994) structure based on the known layout characteristics.
trans-unit.target: [**GetBoundingRectangleCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getboundingrectanglecore): Returns a [**Rect**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225994) structure based on the known layout characteristics.

trans-unit.source: Returns a 0-value **Rect** if [**IsOffscreen**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreen) is **true**.
trans-unit.target: Returns a 0-value **Rect** if [**IsOffscreen**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreen) is **true**.

trans-unit.source: [**GetClickablePointCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclickablepointcore): Returns a [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) structure based on the known layout characteristics, as long as there is a nonzero **BoundingRectangle**.
trans-unit.target: [**GetClickablePointCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getclickablepointcore): Returns a [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) structure based on the known layout characteristics, as long as there is a nonzero **BoundingRectangle**.

trans-unit.source: [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore): More extensive behavior than can be summarized here; see [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore).
trans-unit.target: [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore): More extensive behavior than can be summarized here; see [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore).

trans-unit.source: Basically, it attempts a string conversion on any known content of a [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365) or related classes that have content.
trans-unit.target: Basically, it attempts a string conversion on any known content of a [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209365) or related classes that have content.

trans-unit.source: Also, if there is a value for [**LabeledBy**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh759769), that item's **Name** value is used as the **Name**.
trans-unit.target: Also, if there is a value for [**LabeledBy**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh759769), that item's **Name** value is used as the **Name**.

trans-unit.source: [**HasKeyboardFocusCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_haskeyboardfocuscore): Evaluated based on the owner's [**FocusState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_focusstate) and [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled) properties.
trans-unit.target: [**HasKeyboardFocusCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_haskeyboardfocuscore): Evaluated based on the owner's [**FocusState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_focusstate) and [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled) properties.

trans-unit.source: Elements that aren't controls always return **false**.
trans-unit.target: Elements that aren't controls always return **false**.

trans-unit.source: [**IsEnabledCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isenabledcore): Evaluated based on the owner's [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled) property if it is a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390).
trans-unit.target: [**IsEnabledCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isenabledcore): Evaluated based on the owner's [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled) property if it is a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390).

trans-unit.source: Elements that aren't controls always return **true**.
trans-unit.target: Elements that aren't controls always return **true**.

trans-unit.source: This doesn't mean that the owner is enabled in the conventional interaction sense; it means that the peer is enabled despite the owner not having an **IsEnabled** property.
trans-unit.target: This doesn't mean that the owner is enabled in the conventional interaction sense; it means that the peer is enabled despite the owner not having an **IsEnabled** property.

trans-unit.source: [**IsKeyboardFocusableCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iskeyboardfocusablecore): Returns **true** if owner is a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390); otherwise it is **false**.
trans-unit.target: [**IsKeyboardFocusableCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_iskeyboardfocusablecore): Returns **true** if owner is a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390); otherwise it is **false**.

trans-unit.source: [**IsOffscreenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreencore): A [**Visibility**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_visibility) of [**Hidden**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209006) on the owner element or any of its parents equates to a **true** value for [**IsOffscreen**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreen).
trans-unit.target: [**IsOffscreenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreencore): A [**Visibility**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911_visibility) of [**Hidden**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209006) on the owner element or any of its parents equates to a **true** value for [**IsOffscreen**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_isoffscreen).

trans-unit.source: Exception: a [**Popup**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227842) object can be visible even if its owner's parents are not.
trans-unit.target: Exception: a [**Popup**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227842) object can be visible even if its owner's parents are not.

trans-unit.source: [**SetFocusCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_setfocuscore): Calls [**Focus**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_focus).
trans-unit.target: [**SetFocusCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_setfocuscore): Calls [**Focus**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_focus).

trans-unit.source: [**GetParent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getparent): Calls [**FrameworkElement.Parent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208739) from the owner, and looks up the appropriate peer.
trans-unit.target: [**GetParent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getparent): Calls [**FrameworkElement.Parent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208739) from the owner, and looks up the appropriate peer.

trans-unit.source: This isn't an override pair with a "Core" method, so you can't change this behavior.
trans-unit.target: This isn't an override pair with a "Core" method, so you can't change this behavior.

trans-unit.source: **Note** Default UWP peers implement a behavior by using internal native code that implements the UWP, not necessarily by using actual UWP code.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Default UWP peers implement a behavior by using internal native code that implements the UWP, not necessarily by using actual UWP code.

trans-unit.source: You won't be able to see the code or logic of the implementation through common language runtime (CLR) reflection or other techniques.
trans-unit.target: You won't be able to see the code or logic of the implementation through common language runtime (CLR) reflection or other techniques.

trans-unit.source: You also won't see distinct reference pages for subclass-specific overrides of base peer behavior.
trans-unit.target: You also won't see distinct reference pages for subclass-specific overrides of base peer behavior.

trans-unit.source: For example, there might be additional behavior for [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore) of a [**TextBoxAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242550), which won't be described on the **AutomationPeer.GetNameCore** reference page, and there is no reference page for **TextBoxAutomationPeer.GetNameCore**.
trans-unit.target: For example, there might be additional behavior for [**GetNameCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getnamecore) of a [**TextBoxAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242550), which won't be described on the **AutomationPeer.GetNameCore** reference page, and there is no reference page for **TextBoxAutomationPeer.GetNameCore**.

trans-unit.source: There isn't even a **TextBoxAutomationPeer.GetNameCore** reference page.
trans-unit.target: There isn't even a **TextBoxAutomationPeer.GetNameCore** reference page.

trans-unit.source: Instead, read the reference topic for the most immediate peer class, and look for implementation notes in the Remarks section.
trans-unit.target: Instead, read the reference topic for the most immediate peer class, and look for implementation notes in the Remarks section.

trans-unit.source: Peers and AutomationProperties
trans-unit.target: Peers and AutomationProperties

trans-unit.source: Your automation peer should provide appropriate default values for your control's accessibility-related information.
trans-unit.target: Your automation peer should provide appropriate default values for your control's accessibility-related information.

trans-unit.source: Note that any app code that uses the control can override some of that behavior by including [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) attached-property values on control instances.
trans-unit.target: Note that any app code that uses the control can override some of that behavior by including [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) attached-property values on control instances.

trans-unit.source: Callers can do this either for the default controls or for custom controls.
trans-unit.target: Callers can do this either for the default controls or for custom controls.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following XAML creates a button that has two customized UI Automation properties:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following XAML creates a button that has two customized UI Automation properties:

trans-unit.source: For more info about [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) attached properties, see [Basic accessibility information](basic-accessibility-information.md).
trans-unit.target: For more info about [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) attached properties, see [Basic accessibility information](basic-accessibility-information.md).

trans-unit.source: Some of the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) methods exist because of the general contract of how UI Automation providers are expected to report information, but these methods are not typically implemented in control peers.
trans-unit.target: Some of the [**AutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185) methods exist because of the general contract of how UI Automation providers are expected to report information, but these methods are not typically implemented in control peers.

trans-unit.source: This is because that info is expected to be provided by [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) values applied to the app code that uses the controls in a specific UI.
trans-unit.target: This is because that info is expected to be provided by [**AutomationProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081) values applied to the app code that uses the controls in a specific UI.

trans-unit.source: For example, most apps would define the labeling relationship between two different controls in the UI by applying a [**AutomationProperties.LabeledBy**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh759769) value.
trans-unit.target: For example, most apps would define the labeling relationship between two different controls in the UI by applying a [**AutomationProperties.LabeledBy**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh759769) value.

trans-unit.source: However, [**LabeledByCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlabeledbycore) is implemented in certain peers that represent data or item relationships in a control, such as using a header part to label a data-field part, labeling items with their containers, or similar scenarios.
trans-unit.target: However, [**LabeledByCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getlabeledbycore) is implemented in certain peers that represent data or item relationships in a control, such as using a header part to label a data-field part, labeling items with their containers, or similar scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Implementing patterns
trans-unit.target: Implementing patterns

trans-unit.source: Let's look at how to write a peer for a control that implements an expand-collapse behavior by implementing the control pattern interface for expand-collapse.
trans-unit.target: Let's look at how to write a peer for a control that implements an expand-collapse behavior by implementing the control pattern interface for expand-collapse.

trans-unit.source: The peer should enable the accessibility for the expand-collapse behavior by returning itself whenever [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) is called with a value of [**PatternInterface.ExpandCollapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496).
trans-unit.target: The peer should enable the accessibility for the expand-collapse behavior by returning itself whenever [**GetPattern**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getpattern) is called with a value of [**PatternInterface.ExpandCollapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496).

trans-unit.source: The peer should then inherit the provider interface for that pattern ([**IExpandCollapseProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671242)) and provide implementations for each of the members of that provider interface.
trans-unit.target: The peer should then inherit the provider interface for that pattern ([**IExpandCollapseProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671242)) and provide implementations for each of the members of that provider interface.

trans-unit.source: In this case the interface has three members to override: [**Expand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570), [**Collapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242569), [**ExpandCollapseState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570collapsestate).
trans-unit.target: In this case the interface has three members to override: [**Expand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570), [**Collapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242569), [**ExpandCollapseState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570collapsestate).

trans-unit.source: It's helpful to plan ahead for accessibility in the API design of the class itself.
trans-unit.target: It's helpful to plan ahead for accessibility in the API design of the class itself.

trans-unit.source: Whenever you have a behavior that is potentially requested either as a result of typical interactions with a user who is working in the UI or through an automation provider pattern, provide a single method that either the UI response or the automation pattern can call.
trans-unit.target: Whenever you have a behavior that is potentially requested either as a result of typical interactions with a user who is working in the UI or through an automation provider pattern, provide a single method that either the UI response or the automation pattern can call.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your control has button parts that have wired event handlers that can expand or collapse the control, and has keyboard equivalents for those actions, have these event handlers call the same method that you call from within the body of the [**Expand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570) or [**Collapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242569) implementations for [**IExpandCollapseProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671242) in the peer.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your control has button parts that have wired event handlers that can expand or collapse the control, and has keyboard equivalents for those actions, have these event handlers call the same method that you call from within the body of the [**Expand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242570) or [**Collapse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242569) implementations for [**IExpandCollapseProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671242) in the peer.

trans-unit.source: Using a common logic method can also be a useful way to make sure that your control's visual states are updated to show logical state in a uniform way, regardless of how the behavior was invoked.
trans-unit.target: Using a common logic method can also be a useful way to make sure that your control's visual states are updated to show logical state in a uniform way, regardless of how the behavior was invoked.

trans-unit.source: A typical implementation is that the provider APIs first call [**Owner**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_owner) for access to the control instance at run time.
trans-unit.target: A typical implementation is that the provider APIs first call [**Owner**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472_owner) for access to the control instance at run time.

trans-unit.source: Then the necessary behavior methods can be called on that object.
trans-unit.target: Then the necessary behavior methods can be called on that object.

trans-unit.source: An alternate implementation is that the control itself can reference its peer.
trans-unit.target: An alternate implementation is that the control itself can reference its peer.

trans-unit.source: This is a common pattern if you are raising automation events from the control, because the [**RaiseAutomationEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raiseautomationevent) method is a peer method.
trans-unit.target: This is a common pattern if you are raising automation events from the control, because the [**RaiseAutomationEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raiseautomationevent) method is a peer method.

trans-unit.source: UI Automation events
trans-unit.target: UI Automation events

trans-unit.source: UI Automation events fall into the following categories.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation events fall into the following categories.

trans-unit.source: Event
trans-unit.target: Event

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Property change
trans-unit.target: Property change

trans-unit.source: Fires when a property on a UI Automation element or control pattern changes.
trans-unit.target: Fires when a property on a UI Automation element or control pattern changes.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a client needs to monitor an app's check box control, it can register to listen for a property change event on the [**ToggleState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242653_togglestate) property.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a client needs to monitor an app's check box control, it can register to listen for a property change event on the [**ToggleState**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242653_togglestate) property.

trans-unit.source: When the check box control is checked or unchecked, the provider fires the event and the client can act as necessary.
trans-unit.target: When the check box control is checked or unchecked, the provider fires the event and the client can act as necessary.

trans-unit.source: Element action
trans-unit.target: Element action

trans-unit.source: Fires when a change in the UI results from user or programmatic activity; for example, when a button is clicked or invoked through the **Invoke** pattern.
trans-unit.target: Fires when a change in the UI results from user or programmatic activity; for example, when a button is clicked or invoked through the **Invoke** pattern.

trans-unit.source: Structure change
trans-unit.target: Structure change

trans-unit.source: Fires when the structure of the UI Automation tree changes.
trans-unit.target: Fires when the structure of the UI Automation tree changes.

trans-unit.source: The structure changes when new UI items become visible, hidden, or removed on the desktop.
trans-unit.target: The structure changes when new UI items become visible, hidden, or removed on the desktop.

trans-unit.source: Global change
trans-unit.target: Global change

trans-unit.source: Fires when actions of global interest to the client occur, such as when the focus shifts from one element to another, or when a child window closes.
trans-unit.target: Fires when actions of global interest to the client occur, such as when the focus shifts from one element to another, or when a child window closes.

trans-unit.source: Some events do not necessarily mean that the state of the UI has changed.
trans-unit.target: Some events do not necessarily mean that the state of the UI has changed.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the user tabs to a text-entry field and then clicks a button to update the field, a [**TextChanged**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209683_textchanged) event fires even if the user did not actually change the text.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the user tabs to a text-entry field and then clicks a button to update the field, a [**TextChanged**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209683_textchanged) event fires even if the user did not actually change the text.

trans-unit.source: When processing an event, it may be necessary for a client application to check whether anything has actually changed before taking action.
trans-unit.target: When processing an event, it may be necessary for a client application to check whether anything has actually changed before taking action.

trans-unit.source: AutomationEvents identifiers
trans-unit.target: AutomationEvents identifiers

trans-unit.source: UI Automation events are identified by [**AutomationEvents**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209183) values.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation events are identified by [**AutomationEvents**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209183) values.

trans-unit.source: The values of the enumeration uniquely identify the kind of event.
trans-unit.target: The values of the enumeration uniquely identify the kind of event.

trans-unit.source: Raising events
trans-unit.target: Raising events

trans-unit.source: UI Automation clients can subscribe to automation events.
trans-unit.target: UI Automation clients can subscribe to automation events.

trans-unit.source: In the automation peer model, peers for custom controls must report changes to control state that are relevant to accessibility by calling the [**RaiseAutomationEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raiseautomationevent) method.
trans-unit.target: In the automation peer model, peers for custom controls must report changes to control state that are relevant to accessibility by calling the [**RaiseAutomationEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raiseautomationevent) method.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, when a key UI Automation property value changes, custom control peers should call the [**RaisePropertyChangedEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raisepropertychangedevent) method.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, when a key UI Automation property value changes, custom control peers should call the [**RaisePropertyChangedEvent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_raisepropertychangedevent) method.

trans-unit.source: The next code example shows how to get the peer object from within the control definition code and call a method to fire an event from that peer.
trans-unit.target: The next code example shows how to get the peer object from within the control definition code and call a method to fire an event from that peer.

trans-unit.source: As an optimization, the code determines whether there are any listeners for this event type.
trans-unit.target: As an optimization, the code determines whether there are any listeners for this event type.

trans-unit.source: Firing the event and creating the peer object only when there are listeners avoids unnecessary overhead and helps the control remain responsive.
trans-unit.target: Firing the event and creating the peer object only when there are listeners avoids unnecessary overhead and helps the control remain responsive.

trans-unit.source: Peer navigation
trans-unit.target: Peer navigation

trans-unit.source: After locating an automation peer, a UI Automation client can navigate the peer structure of an app by calling the peer object's [**GetChildren**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildren) and [**GetParent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getparent) methods.
trans-unit.target: After locating an automation peer, a UI Automation client can navigate the peer structure of an app by calling the peer object's [**GetChildren**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildren) and [**GetParent**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getparent) methods.

trans-unit.source: Navigation among UI elements within a control is supported by the peer's implementation of the [**GetChildrenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildrencore) method.
trans-unit.target: Navigation among UI elements within a control is supported by the peer's implementation of the [**GetChildrenCore**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209185_getchildrencore) method.

trans-unit.source: The UI Automation system calls this method to build up a tree of subelements contained within a control; for example, list items in a list box.
trans-unit.target: The UI Automation system calls this method to build up a tree of subelements contained within a control; for example, list items in a list box.

trans-unit.source: The default **GetChildrenCore** method in [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) traverses the visual tree of elements to build the tree of automation peers.
trans-unit.target: The default **GetChildrenCore** method in [**FrameworkElementAutomationPeer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242472) traverses the visual tree of elements to build the tree of automation peers.

trans-unit.source: Custom controls can override this method to expose a different representation of child elements to automation clients, returning the automation peers of elements that convey information or allow user interaction.
trans-unit.target: Custom controls can override this method to expose a different representation of child elements to automation clients, returning the automation peers of elements that convey information or allow user interaction.

trans-unit.source: Native automation support for text patterns
trans-unit.target: Native automation support for text patterns

trans-unit.source: Some of the default UWP app automation peers provide control pattern support for the text pattern ([**PatternInterface.Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496)).
trans-unit.target: Some of the default UWP app automation peers provide control pattern support for the text pattern ([**PatternInterface.Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242496)).

trans-unit.source: But they provide this support through native methods, and the peers involved won't note the [**ITextProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242627) interface in the (managed) inheritance.
trans-unit.target: But they provide this support through native methods, and the peers involved won't note the [**ITextProvider**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242627) interface in the (managed) inheritance.

trans-unit.source: Still, if a managed or non-managed UI Automation client queries the peer for patterns, it will report support for the text pattern, and provide behavior for parts of the pattern when client APIs are called.
trans-unit.target: Still, if a managed or non-managed UI Automation client queries the peer for patterns, it will report support for the text pattern, and provide behavior for parts of the pattern when client APIs are called.

trans-unit.source: If you intend to derive from one of the UWP app text controls and also create a custom peer that derives from one of the text-related peers, check the Remarks sections for the peer to learn more about any native-level support for patterns.
trans-unit.target: If you intend to derive from one of the UWP app text controls and also create a custom peer that derives from one of the text-related peers, check the Remarks sections for the peer to learn more about any native-level support for patterns.

trans-unit.source: You can access the native base behavior in your custom peer if you call the base implementation from your managed provider interface implementations, but it's difficult to modify what the base implementation does because the native interfaces on both the peer and its owner control aren't exposed.
trans-unit.target: You can access the native base behavior in your custom peer if you call the base implementation from your managed provider interface implementations, but it's difficult to modify what the base implementation does because the native interfaces on both the peer and its owner control aren't exposed.

trans-unit.source: Generally you should either use the base implementations as-is (call base only) or completely replace the functionality with your own managed code and don't call the base implementation.
trans-unit.target: Generally you should either use the base implementations as-is (call base only) or completely replace the functionality with your own managed code and don't call the base implementation.

trans-unit.source: The latter is an advanced scenario, you'll need good familiarity with the text services framework being used by your control in order to support the accessibility requirements when using that framework.
trans-unit.target: The latter is an advanced scenario, you'll need good familiarity with the text services framework being used by your control in order to support the accessibility requirements when using that framework.

trans-unit.source: AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView
trans-unit.target: AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView

trans-unit.source: In addition to providing a custom peer, you can also adjust the tree view representation for any control instance, by setting [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview) in XAML.
trans-unit.target: In addition to providing a custom peer, you can also adjust the tree view representation for any control instance, by setting [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview) in XAML.

trans-unit.source: This isn't implemented as part of a peer class, but we'll mention it here because it's germane to overall accessibility support either for custom controls or for templates you customize.
trans-unit.target: This isn't implemented as part of a peer class, but we'll mention it here because it's germane to overall accessibility support either for custom controls or for templates you customize.

trans-unit.source: The main scenario for using [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview) is to deliberately omit certain controls in a template from the UI Automation views, because they don't meaningfully contribute to the accessibility view of the entire control.
trans-unit.target: The main scenario for using [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview) is to deliberately omit certain controls in a template from the UI Automation views, because they don't meaningfully contribute to the accessibility view of the entire control.

trans-unit.source: To prevent this, set **AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView** to "Raw".
trans-unit.target: To prevent this, set **AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView** to "Raw".

trans-unit.source: For more info, see [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview).
trans-unit.target: For more info, see [**AutomationProperties.AccessibilityView**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209081_accessibilityview).

trans-unit.source: Throwing exceptions from automation peers
trans-unit.target: Throwing exceptions from automation peers

trans-unit.source: The APIs that you are implementing for your automation peer support are permitted to throw exceptions.
trans-unit.target: The APIs that you are implementing for your automation peer support are permitted to throw exceptions.

trans-unit.source: It's expected any UI Automation clients that are listening are robust enough to continue on after most exceptions are thrown.
trans-unit.target: It's expected any UI Automation clients that are listening are robust enough to continue on after most exceptions are thrown.

trans-unit.source: In all likelihood that listener is looking at an all-up automation tree that includes apps other than your own, and it's an unacceptable client design to bring down the entire client just because one area of the tree threw a peer-based exception when the client called its APIs.
trans-unit.target: In all likelihood that listener is looking at an all-up automation tree that includes apps other than your own, and it's an unacceptable client design to bring down the entire client just because one area of the tree threw a peer-based exception when the client called its APIs.

trans-unit.source: For parameters that are passed in to your peer, it's acceptable to validate the input, and for example throw [**ArgumentNullException**](T:System.ArgumentNullException) if it was passed **null** and that's not a valid value for your implementation.
trans-unit.target: For parameters that are passed in to your peer, it's acceptable to validate the input, and for example throw [**ArgumentNullException**](T:System.ArgumentNullException) if it was passed **null** and that's not a valid value for your implementation.

trans-unit.source: However, if there are subsequent operations performed by your peer, remember that the peer's interactions with the hosting control have something of an asynchronous character to them.
trans-unit.target: However, if there are subsequent operations performed by your peer, remember that the peer's interactions with the hosting control have something of an asynchronous character to them.

trans-unit.source: Anything a peer does won't necessarily block the UI thread in the control (and it probably shouldn't).
trans-unit.target: Anything a peer does won't necessarily block the UI thread in the control (and it probably shouldn't).

trans-unit.source: So you could have situations where an object was available or had certain properties when the peer was created or when an automation peer method was first called, but in the meantime the control state has changed.
trans-unit.target: So you could have situations where an object was available or had certain properties when the peer was created or when an automation peer method was first called, but in the meantime the control state has changed.

trans-unit.source: For these cases, there are two dedicated exceptions that a provider can throw:
trans-unit.target: For these cases, there are two dedicated exceptions that a provider can throw:

trans-unit.source: Throw [**ElementNotAvailableException**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh673741) if you're unable to access either the peer's owner or a related peer element based on the original info your API was passed.
trans-unit.target: Throw [**ElementNotAvailableException**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh673741) if you're unable to access either the peer's owner or a related peer element based on the original info your API was passed.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might have a peer that's trying to run its methods but the owner has since been removed from the UI, such as a modal dialog that's been closed.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might have a peer that's trying to run its methods but the owner has since been removed from the UI, such as a modal dialog that's been closed.

trans-unit.source: For a non-.NET client, this maps to [**UIA\_E\_ELEMENTNOTAVAILABLE**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671218).
trans-unit.target: For a non-.NET client, this maps to [**UIA\_E\_ELEMENTNOTAVAILABLE**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671218).

trans-unit.source: Throw [**ElementNotEnabledException**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh673748) if there still is an owner, but that owner is in a mode such as [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled)`=`**false** that's blocking some of the specific programmatic changes that your peer is trying to accomplish.
trans-unit.target: Throw [**ElementNotEnabledException**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh673748) if there still is an owner, but that owner is in a mode such as [**IsEnabled**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR209390_isenabled)`=`**false** that's blocking some of the specific programmatic changes that your peer is trying to accomplish.

trans-unit.source: For a non-.NET client, this maps to [**UIA\_E\_ELEMENTNOTENABLED**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671218).
trans-unit.target: For a non-.NET client, this maps to [**UIA\_E\_ELEMENTNOTENABLED**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/Ee671218).

trans-unit.source: Beyond this, peers should be relatively conservative regarding exceptions that they throw from their peer support.
trans-unit.target: Beyond this, peers should be relatively conservative regarding exceptions that they throw from their peer support.

trans-unit.source: Most clients won't be able to handle exceptions from peers and turn these into actionable choices that their users can make when interacting with the client.
trans-unit.target: Most clients won't be able to handle exceptions from peers and turn these into actionable choices that their users can make when interacting with the client.

trans-unit.source: So sometimes a no-op, and catching exceptions without rethrowing within your peer implementations, is a better strategy than is throwing exceptions every time something the peer tries to do doesn't work.
trans-unit.target: So sometimes a no-op, and catching exceptions without rethrowing within your peer implementations, is a better strategy than is throwing exceptions every time something the peer tries to do doesn't work.

trans-unit.source: Consider also that most UI Automation clients aren't written in managed code.
trans-unit.target: Consider also that most UI Automation clients aren't written in managed code.

trans-unit.source: Most are written in COM and are just checking for **S\_OK** in an **HRESULT** whenever they call a UI Automation client method that ends up accessing your peer.
trans-unit.target: Most are written in COM and are just checking for **S\_OK** in an **HRESULT** whenever they call a UI Automation client method that ends up accessing your peer.
